body:
Thanks for taking this on:

The idea was for the splitter function to have the signature `Function<T,E>` where E is the enum type, so that the application developer just uses enum constants rather than integers.

For example if one was splitting on the severity of a log event and the log event class has a `Severity getSeverity()` method where Severity is an enum, then the split would look something like:

`List<TStream<LogEvent>>  splits = logEvents.split(Severity.class, e -> e.getSeverity());`

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/QUARKS-18

I also think it's possible to implement this by having the new split method that takes an enum just call the  existing split method, using a function that wraps the user's enum split function and returns the enum's ordinal().

I wonder if this enum split should return:

`List<TStream<T>>` // like the existing split, the list would be ordered by the enum ordinals

OR

`EnumMap<E,TStream<T>>`  // possibly more natural for enums since ordinal() does say ' Most programmers will have no use for this method.'

Example use of first (with an example Severity enum of HIGH, LOW)

```
TStream<LogEvent> highStream = splits.get(HIGH.ordinal());
TStream<LogEvent> lowStream = splits.get(LOW.ordinal());
```

I think the map approach cleans this up to:

```
TStream<LogEvent> highStream = splits.get(HIGH);
TStream<LogEvent> lowStream = splits.get(LOW);
```

Good day Debrunner thank you for your pointing
I will check it and modify PR after company work
Have a good day

Test added in [PR 30](https://github.com/apache/incubator-quarks/pull/30)

I assume you don't see the problem because your workspace has an jobregistry/src/test/java directory.  Empty dirs aren't captured by git so when someone picks up this merge their eclipse workspace lacks the dir and they see the problem.

Note, an ant build, in order to avoid a similar problem, auto-creates empty src/test/java dirs.  So after that's done the eclipse problem doesn't occur.

Remove the empty dir in your workspace to see the exact problems that eclipse generates.  You may need to refresh the workspace and force a project build and/or restart eclipse for it to pickup on the removal.

```
/** (a..*) (exclusive) */

```

@Cazen 

The extra commits don't seem to be an issue but this is what I'm doing to keep my fork up to date:
- Don't use the ASF repo, only this mirror and your fork of this mirror. I.e. don't set any remotes pointing to the ASF repo.
- Never make changes to the master branch on your fork, always do any development on a branch, branches are cheap.
- Rebase your fork using this: https://github.com/IBMStreams/streamsx.topology/wiki/Useful-Git-GitHub-info which refers to http://blog.bigbinary.com/2013/09/13/how-to-keep-your-fork-uptodate.html

Yup, I'll improve the javadoc.

Re: should it implement Predicate?  I think the answer is "no".  I believe Range isa Predicate is only useful if the stream's tuples are "primitive" types (e.g., Integer).  In the probably very rare case where there is such a stream, lambda expressions make it trivial for the user to just supply `tuple -> myRange.contains(tuple)` (instead of just `myRange`).   Fwiw, while Guava Range implements its Predicate, the test() override is documented as deprecated and says callers should just use "contains()".  Seems like they now regret it being a Predicate.  Actually, for a short time I had this Range implement quarks Predicate and removed it :-)

I've carefully read your mention and it looks very helpful to me.
I'll apply it to my next work! Thank you @ddebrunner Have a good day!
@dlaboss Could you expand on why it's not useful when the tuples are not wrapper classes?

If "simple" streams like `TStream<Integer>` aren't likely then this seemed unnecessary:

```
TStream<Integer> s = ...
TStream<Integer> filtered = s.filter(myRange);  // vs t -> myRange.contains(t)
```

Hmm... I guess I hadn't considered a case like Filters.deadband() where a "simple type" Predicate must be supplied for a type already extracted from a more complex tuple.  e.g.,

```
TStream<JsonObject> readings = ...
Range<Double> deadbandRange = Range.closed(10.0d, 30.0d);
TStream<JsonObject> filtered = Filters.deadband(readings,
                           tuple -> tuple.get("reading").getAsDouble(),
                           deadbandRange);    // vs   v -> deadbandRange.contains(v)
```

@ddebrunner is that sufficient rationale for making Range a Predicate?  Including in light of Guava Range's seemingly regret about that [here](https://github.com/google/guava/blob/master/guava/src/com/google/common/collect/Range.java#L436)?
@dlaboss Maybe I'm misunderstanding what Range can be used for. Can Range be used on a arbitrary Java class that implements Comparable? If so then why is Range as a Predicate not useful in that case?
I saw something recently that said the NOTICE file must only include notices that must be there, so I'd like to hold off on merging this to understand if each notice must be copied there.

> Do not add anything to NOTICE which is not legally required.

http://www.apache.org/dev/licensing-howto.html

For example, why is software distributed under the Eclipse Public Licence listed in the notice?

It's a category B licence:
http://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-b

Currently the top-level LICENSE and NOTICE file are copied into each jar.

Seems that with these files fully completed (this pr and #57) that may no longer be the correct approach.

For example the scala licence added by #57 only is applicable for the Kafka connector, so why should it appear in every other jar?

So there are a couple of comments saying changes will be made in response to comments.

Will those changes be under this pull request, do they need to be under this pull request or can it be merged without the changes?

OK you caught me :-)  As was noted in the javadoc the initial implementation only supported a subset of Comparables: Integer,Long,Short,Byte,Float,Double,BigInteger,BigDecimal.  I've revisited things to remove that restriction.  

I've also added "implements Predicate".  Can you provide a sample  / pseudo code for a non-trivial case where and how you want to be using that fact so I can ensure that need is met.

I'll be pushing changes for the above and other issues raised shortly.

Good Day [~dlaboss] Thank you for advising :) - The image rendering was good. I can see the picture properly. But in Java8, There are strict rules when generate JavaDoc(it's not valid in HTML) ``` Filters.java:102: error: self-closing element not allowed * ^ ``` Of course, we can just using -Xdoclint:none option to turn off, But I thought it's good to remove self-closing tag for avoid confusing. - I can see the '>' character in JavaDoc from Connector.java:49 of master branch correctly. I just change it to with escapse, because it cause JavaDoc generate error. ``` Connector.java:49: error: bad use of '>' * -->C1 ^ ``` But I think it's good idea to using '@code' tag rather than using escape like you mentioned. I will change it immediately. - `` tag and `{@code}` tag are different in JavaDoc(http://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/technotes/tools/windows/javadoc.html) `` tag does not replace "<" or ">" automatically. It cause error ``` {@code text} Introduced in JDK 1.5 Equivalent to {@literal}. Displays text in code font without interpreting the text as HTML markup or nested Javadoc tags. This enables you to use regular angle brackets (< and >) instead of the HTML entities (< and >) in documentation comments, such as in parameter types (
Closing this pull request; I plan to update notice file in smaller increments.

Ah, thanks for the clarification on and the other problems. If something needs to be fixed and using {@code} works then that seems like the best solution to me. I didn't mean to imply that you _should_ hunt down and convert all uses of <code>, even non-problem ones, to using {@code} though that may help avoid future problems... and I would support your efforts :-)

I really appreciate your review @dlaboss :)
Have a good day!

The project really appreciates your contributions!
If you are going to make more changes it would be good to add [WIP] to the title of the PR until your final set of changes are all set to go / ready for review and merging.

- sankey_quarks.js is under BSD 3-Clause License(https://opensource.org/licenses/BSD-3-Clause). So no license header needed.
- But, in case of d3.BSD.LICENSE, sankey.d3.BSD.LICENSE, it looks like just license template.
  Could I change it in order to original d3 license?
  
  d3.BSD.LICENSE - https://github.com/mbostock/d3/blob/master/LICENSE
  sankey.d3.BSD.LICENSE - https://github.com/d3/d3-plugins/blob/master/LICENSE
Should we be changing headers on third party files (anything under `ext`)?

Good Day @ddebrunner 
- We need only attach header to source file that we've created
  (http://www.apache.org/legal/src-headers.html -> SOURCE FILE HEADERS FOR CODE DEVELOPED AT THE ASF)
- But, in case of graph.js, index.js, metrics.js, it looks like our own source code. So I've worked on it. ->(edited: sorry for confusing, these files not in ext folder)
- D3 related js files are under BSD license. So I didn't attach Apache license headers on that(TREATMENT OF THIRD-PARTY WORKS)

I could have been misunderstood your question
If your question is about d3.BSD.LICENSE, sankey.d3.BSD.LICENSE, and you think that it is better to keep them all, please just tell me.
I thought it's weird that the license looks just a BSD template when I searched about BSD license usage in other Apache project(e.g https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/master/licenses/LICENSE-d3.min.js.txt)
Please don't hesitate to advise me.

Commit 1e154be8668c06e2b6d18c0eb12306f35cd23d07 is good. It is adding a licence header to Quarks code.

Commit 2fd31c76da043e53391c51c0503fd1df5df802be is not. Any file under an `ext` folder is a third-party distribution (or subset of a distribution). We should not be modifying third-party files, especially modifying their licence/notice files.

Now maybe there is an issue with what is in that `ext` directory, but that I think that would be better covered as a separate issue where a discussion of the correct fix (if any) can take place.

In general it's better to have pull requests and issues focus on a single topic, rather than combining multiple unrelated items. Merging pull requests is easy for committers so don't worry about creating many, the more focused a set of changes the more likely they will be merged quickly.

So I'm -1 on this pull request, but if 1e154be8668c06e2b6d18c0eb12306f35cd23d07  (or its changes) was submitted as a new pull request that would be merged quickly.
That's cool, if you put the full commit id in a comment, it gets auto-linked to the commit.

perhaps a stupid question:  I'm missing the need for / benefit of the cron aspect of this solution.  Why not just have a start script that loops: run the app in the foreground and when it exits, simply restart it... and avoid the cron stuff?

I worried how I can revert the commit 2fd31c7, decided to resolve the issue through revert.(https://github.com/blog/2019-how-to-undo-almost-anything-with-git) I think our discussion history will be lost if I rebase my branch in this commit.
I will revert wrong commit immediately. I agree it's better that PR should concentrate one issue rather than more. And license is sensitive issue, too. I will note.
Text comment that linking to commit is good function in github. That's interesting. haha

I think the safe way is to create a new branch in your fork and cherry-pick 1e154be8668c06e2b6d18c0eb12306f35cd23d07
so that the actual repo shows no changes to the files under ext.
I was thinking the same thing, but then what happens if that looping script dies?
@dlaboss one can use cron to run a command at boot time without having root access, for example for starting a Quarks application.
Why not? I will follow your way. Thank you
@dlaboss, looks great! It will greatly simplify the existing recipes.

I made the following changes based on your feedback:
- startapp.sh is reusable - it takes the class path and the name of the class to be launched as command line arguments.  It also uses JAVA_HOME, rather than expecting java to be in the path.
- startapp.cron is a sample crontab entry for restarting sample TerminateAfterNTuples every minute

FYI - no need to ask a specific person to review a request.

Anyone (contributor or committer) can review and make comments on a pull request
